title: How to Clean Chairs

steps.headline: Vacuum the chair to get rid of stuck-on dirt.
steps.description: Before washing your chair, vacuum the entire surface you are going to clean. This will get rid of any dirt that you don’t want to spread while you’re cleaning. Use a vacuum with an upholstery attachment, because it will loosen any dry dirt that you may not be able to see. If your vacuum has a crevice tool attachment, use that for hard to reach areas and corners.

steps.headline: Use baby wipes to clean small stains on microfiber couches.
steps.description: Baby wipes work well on upholstery, especially if the stain is new. They use very little moisture and are mild so you don’t have to worry about ruining your furniture. Keep them nearby any furniture with upholstery, because they will work best if you use it right after you spill something. When cleaning with a baby wipe, use a dabbing motion so you don’t grind the stain further into the upholstery. Avoid using baby wipes on leather furniture.

steps.headline: Check the upholstery cleaning code.
steps.description: Before cleaning your chair, make sure you’re following the manufacturer’s upholstery cleaning instructions. Your chair will have a code, which indicates what to use and what not to use when cleaning. This code is usually found on a tag under the cushion. “W” means it is okay to use water. Most couches this code are man-made and are typically polyester or nylon. “S” means clean only with dry cleaning solvents. These fabrics are organic fibers, and typically include cotton, rayon, and linen. “S/W” means you can use either dry cleaning solvents or water. “X” means avoid using both solvents and water. To clean, vacuum or brush only.

steps.headline: Use soap and water to clean chairs with "W" upholstery codes.
steps.description: Add a few drops of mild dish soap to a clean bucket. Fill the bucket with warm water, then dip a soft-bristled brush into the solution. Mix it together with the brush until suds form and scrub the fabric gently until the area is clean. Avoid soaking the upholstery, as too much water can cause fabric discoloration. Just make sure it’s lightly damp. When you’re finished, wipe the soapy area with a damp cloth and let it dry. Grab a clean cloth, wet it with water, and wring it until it is just damp. Wipe the area you just scrubbed until there is no visible soapy residue. Let the area completely dry before sitting on it. Do not use a blow dryer to speed up the drying process. It can cause your upholstery to shrink. Instead, turn on any room fans to increase air circulation in the room.

steps.headline: Purchase a water-free or dry cleaning solvent for “S” code upholstery.
steps.description: If your fabric chair has an “S” code, do not use a water-based cleaner. You will need to purchase a mild water-free or dry cleaning solvent to clean your chair. They can be found online or in most popular furniture and department stores. To use this solvent, apply it to a clean towel and gently brush over any dirty areas of your chair. You can also use a soft-bristled brush with the dry cleaning solvent to clean tough spots. After applying the dry-cleaning solvent, dry the area with a blow dryer set to medium heat. Hold the dryer 4 inches (10 cm) away from the fabric and move it back and forth until it is dry to prevent the solvent from leaving a ring on the fabric.

steps.headline: Test water-based cleaners and dry cleaning solvents for “S/W” upholstery codes.
steps.description: If you find that your furniture has this “S/W” code, test your choice of cleaner (water-based or dry cleaning solvent) on a small, inconspicuous spot before cleaning your stain. If there is no damage or to your upholstery with your chosen mixture, then it is safe to use it as a cleaner. For best results, use dry solvents for oily areas and water-based cleaners for wet spots. This code is rare, and it is best to contact the manufacturer or a furniture professional to determine the best way to clean stains on upholstery with this code.

steps.headline: Use a vacuum or brush to clean chairs with an “X” code.
steps.description: Do not use water or solvent on chairs that have this code. These products may cause damage to your upholstery, such as shrinking or discoloration. Instead, only use a vacuum or soft brush to get rid of dry dirt or debris on these fabrics. If you do get a wet spill or stain on this fabric, take it to a local furniture restoration shop to get cleaning advice from a professional.

steps.headline: Vacuum the chair to remove dust and debris.
steps.description: Before washing your chair, vacuum the entire surface. This will remove any dust and dirt on the chair. Make sure you vacuum thoroughly enough to remove all of the dust and grime from your chair. If you don’t vacuum, the abrasive debris could be rubbed in the material when you wipe it with your cleaning solution. Use a soft brush attachment if your vacuum has one. Make sure the bristles are soft, as leather can scratch easily.

steps.headline: Get rid of dark grease stains with a dry cloth.
steps.description: Leather couches are often susceptible to unsightly grease stains. Try to remove these stains as soon as you notice them because grease can soak in the leather if not treated immediately. All you’ll need to do is use is a dry cloth and wipe it away. Press down hard while wiping until all of the grease is gone. If the grease has been on the leather for a while, sprinkle baking powder on the stain and leave it on for a few hours. This will help to draw out the grease. Then brush off the powder with a dry rag and the stain should be gone.

steps.headline: Remove ink stains from finished leather with liquid soap, rubbing alcohol, or cuticle remover.
steps.description: An ink stain is the last thing you want on leather furniture. Luckily, there are a few different methods to try to get rid of it. These methods only work on finished leather, so if you have unfinished leather, you may need to seek a professional to remove these types of stains. Apply a few drops of mild liquid soap to a white cloth and use it to blot the stain. Do this until the stain has completely disappeared. Avoid scrubbing the stain; you may spread it and make it worse. To use rubbing alcohol, dip a cotton swab in the alcohol, then gently dab the ink stain with it. Do not spread the ink while doing this. Once the ink stain has disappeared and the rubbing alcohol dries, use leather conditioner to bring moisture back into the leather. Alcohol may make it appear dry or cracked. Cuticle remover can also be used to remove ink stains from leather. You can find it at most beauty supply stores, but be sure to choose one that has a non-oil based formula. Apply a thick layer with a cotton swab, let it soak for 24 hours, then dab it with a clean white cloth. Your ink stain should disappear!

steps.headline: Prepare a diluted soap mixture with distilled water and mild soap.
steps.description: Mix a few drops of liquid soap into a bucket of water. Make sure the soap is mild and has a neutral pH. Do not use detergent on leather. Mix it with a spoon until suds form in the container. This will be the solution you use to clean your leather chair. You can also use diluted vinegar instead of the soap mixture. To do this, mix equal parts distilled white vinegar and water in a small bucket. Vinegar is a cheap and natural way to kill bacteria, and a great deodorizer on fabrics. The smell may be unpleasant at first, but it gradually dissipates with time.

steps.headline: Use a damp rag to apply and wipe the mixture on your chair.
steps.description: Dip a clean rag in the soap mixture and wring it out until it is damp. It’s important that you don’t soak the chair because that could ruin the leather. Then wipe the leather surface of your chair with the damp rag. Focus on areas of the chair that are dirty. Once you have cleaned it, get a new dry rag to wipe away the soap residue from the chair. If you are cleaning a large surface, rinse and wring the cloth every few strokes so you don’t spread any dirt.

steps.headline: Dry the area with a clean rag.
steps.description: Once you have finished cleaning the leather and have wiped away the soap or vinegar residue, get a dry cloth to wipe all the water. You want to dry the leather as much as you can in this step because you don’t want water to sit on your leather. After drying, you can use an additional clean rag to buff the surface of the leather.

steps.headline: Condition the leather after washing.
steps.description: After you’ve cleaned your leather chair, you may want to treat the surface by using your choice of leather protector. A leather conditioner can be found at most department stores. To use, follow instructions on the bottle. Spray or pour the liquid on a lint-free cloth and apply it to your chair in a circular motion. Use it every 6-12 months to keep your chair soft and supple. Before using any leather conditioner on your furniture, check the care label on your chair and the instructions for using the product.

steps.headline: Dust the entire surface of the chair with a duster or microfiber cloth.
steps.description: The first step for cleaning a wooden chair is to remove any dust. You can use a simple microfiber cloth to do this. Just use a sweeping motion to wipe the cloth back and forth on the chair surface until all dust and dirt is gone. If your wooden chair is made of finished wood, you can spray some water on the cloth before wiping it. If your chair is made from unfinished wood, avoid water because it can distort the wood. You may also use a vacuum to remove the dust. However, do not use an upholstery attachment that spins, as it may damage the wooden surface.

steps.headline: Use a store-bought cleaner to wash finished wood with a clean rag.
steps.description: You can find a cleaner made especially for wood at any hardware or home goods store. Find one has all-natural ingredients, is biodegradable, and specifically designed to disinfect and remove wax and grime. Before applying, read the manufacturer’s instructions. For most cleaners, you will need to spray it on a rag, and then apply 1 coat by wiping the entire surface. Let it stand for 10 minutes for the cleaner to do its work, then wipe again with a damp cloth to remove any residue. You may need to repeat this process 2-3 more times for a complete cleaning. Cheesecloth is great for cleaning wood surfaces. Use a toothbrush or cotton swab to clean corners and crevices. If you prefer to make your own wood cleaner, you can use vinegar and water. All you need to do is mix ⁄2 cup (120 mL) of white vinegar with ⁄2 litre (0.13 US gal) of warm water. Use a spray bottle to spray the mixture on a clean cloth. Be careful not to use too much water. Then, gently wipe your chair with the cloth.

steps.headline: Clean unvarnished wood with a homemade mixture.
steps.description: To clean unfinished wooden chairs you’ll need to fill a large bowl with water. Then add just a splash of each of the following ingredients: dish detergent, baking soda, vinegar, and olive oil. Mix everything together with a spoon. Then, dip a scrubbing sponge in the mixture, wring it out until it is just damp, and then use the abrasive side to wipe down the chair. Once you’re finished, use a clean cloth to dry the entire surface. When cleaning unvarnished wood, word quickly and don’t use too much water. If you’re not careful, water can soak into the wood and cause it to warp or become discolored.

steps.headline: Remove permanent marker stains from wood with toothpaste and baking soda.
steps.description: If you accidentally get marker on your wooden chair, you can get rid of it with baking soda toothpaste. To do this, apply a large glob of toothpaste to a cotton pad. Rub the toothpaste on the stain back and forth along the grain of the wood. You may need to reapply the toothpaste and repeat this step 2-3 times until the marker is completely gone. If you don’t have baking soda toothpaste, you can always add a little bit of baking soda to your regular toothpaste. Do not use gel toothpaste, it does not work to remove marker stains.

steps.headline: Allow the chair to dry for 24 hours.
steps.description: After cleaning your wooden chair, make sure it dries completely. If you cleaned the entire chair, this may take an entire day. If you only cleaned a small spot, this may only take 10-15 minutes. You’ll want to make sure it’s dry before sitting in it or applying any furniture wax.

steps.headline: Restore your wooden chair with wood wax.
steps.description: Cleaning wood may fade some of the polish, which can be quickly restored using wood wax. You can purchase wood wax at most hardware stores. Read the label for proper application to your wood surface. You can apply wood wax with a paintbrush. To do this dip a wide brush in the wood wax, then brush it on the wood back and forth until the wood is shiny. If you use a cloth to apply the wax, make sure it is lint-free. Pour a generous amount of wax on the cloth, then rub it in a circular motion across the entire chair to buff it until you get an even, shiny coat. You can make your own wood wax with a mixture of vinegar and olive oil. Mix ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of olive oil and ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of water in a bowl. Then, use a cloth to apply the mixture and polish your wooden chair.

Use a damp rag to apply and wipe the mixture on your chair.
Dip a clean rag in the soap mixture and wring it out until it is damp.
It’s important that you don’t soak the chair because that could ruin the leather.
Then wipe the leather surface of your chair with the damp rag.
Focus on areas of the chair that are dirty.
Once you have cleaned it, get a new dry rag to wipe away the soap residue from the chair.
If you are cleaning a large surface, rinse and wring the cloth every few strokes so you don’t spread any dirt.
Dry the area with a clean rag.
Once you have finished cleaning the leather and have wiped away the soap or vinegar residue, get a dry cloth to wipe all the water.
You want to dry the leather as much as you can in this step because you don’t want water to sit on your leather.
After drying, you can use an additional clean rag to buff the surface of the leather.
Condition the leather after washing.
After you’ve cleaned your leather chair, you may want to treat the surface by using your choice of leather protector.
A leather conditioner can be found at most department stores.
To use, follow instructions on the bottle.
Spray or pour the liquid on a lint-free cloth and apply it to your chair in a circular motion.
Use it every 6-12 months to keep your chair soft and supple.
Before using any leather conditioner on your furniture, check the care label on your chair and the instructions for using the product.
Cleaning Wooden Chairs Dust the entire surface of the chair with a duster or microfiber cloth.
The first step for cleaning a wooden chair is to remove any dust.
You can use a simple microfiber cloth to do this.
Just use a sweeping motion to wipe the cloth back and forth on the chair surface until all dust and dirt is gone.
If your wooden chair is made of finished wood, you can spray some water on the cloth before wiping it.
If your chair is made from unfinished wood, avoid water because it can distort the wood.
You may also use a vacuum to remove the dust.
However, do not use an upholstery attachment that spins, as it may damage the wooden surface.
Use a store-bought cleaner to wash finished wood with a clean rag.
You can find a cleaner made especially for wood at any hardware or home goods store.
Find one has all-natural ingredients, is biodegradable, and specifically designed to disinfect and remove wax and grime.
Before applying, read the manufacturer’s instructions.
For most cleaners, you will need to spray it on a rag, and then apply 1 coat by wiping the entire surface.
Let it stand for 10 minutes for the cleaner to do its work, then wipe again with a damp cloth to remove any residue.
You may need to repeat this process 2-3 more times for a complete cleaning.
Cheesecloth is great for cleaning wood surfaces.
Use a toothbrush or cotton swab to clean corners and crevices.
If you prefer to make your own wood cleaner, you can use vinegar and water.
All you need to do is mix ⁄2 cup (120 mL) of white vinegar with ⁄2 litre (0.13 US gal) of warm water.
Use a spray bottle to spray the mixture on a clean cloth.
Be careful not to use too much water.
Then, gently wipe your chair with the cloth.
Clean unvarnished wood with a homemade mixture.
To clean unfinished wooden chairs you’ll need to fill a large bowl with water.
Then add just a splash of each of the following ingredients: dish detergent, baking soda, vinegar, and olive oil.
Mix everything together with a spoon.
Then, dip a scrubbing sponge in the mixture, wring it out until it is just damp, and then use the abrasive side to wipe down the chair.
Once you’re finished, use a clean cloth to dry the entire surface.
When cleaning unvarnished wood, word quickly and don’t use too much water.
If you’re not careful, water can soak into the wood and cause it to warp or become discolored.
Remove permanent marker stains from wood with toothpaste and baking soda.
If you accidentally get marker on your wooden chair, you can get rid of it with baking soda toothpaste.
To do this, apply a large glob of toothpaste to a cotton pad.
Rub the toothpaste on the stain back and forth along the grain of the wood.
You may need to reapply the toothpaste and repeat this step 2-3 times until the marker is completely gone.
If you don’t have baking soda toothpaste, you can always add a little bit of baking soda to your regular toothpaste.
Do not use gel toothpaste, it does not work to remove marker stains.
Allow the chair to dry for 24 hours.
After cleaning your wooden chair, make sure it dries completely.
If you cleaned the entire chair, this may take an entire day.
If you only cleaned a small spot, this may only take 10-15 minutes.
You’ll want to make sure it’s dry before sitting in it or applying any furniture wax.
Restore your wooden chair with wood wax.
Cleaning wood may fade some of the polish, which can be quickly restored using wood wax.
You can purchase wood wax at most hardware stores.
Read the label for proper application to your wood surface.
You can apply wood wax with a paintbrush.
To do this dip a wide brush in the wood wax, then brush it on the wood back and forth until the wood is shiny.
If you use a cloth to apply the wax, make sure it is lint-free.
Pour a generous amount of wax on the cloth, then rub it in a circular motion across the entire chair to buff it until you get an even, shiny coat.
You can make your own wood wax with a mixture of vinegar and olive oil.
Mix ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of olive oil and ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of water in a bowl.
Then, use a cloth to apply the mixture and polish your wooden chair.
